title: ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: 'al' with some tracks when synced is enabled as a lyrics provider

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### System OS

Windows

### Python Version

3.11 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

v4.1.7

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

_No response_

### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links!

title: AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'lower' with some tracks when synced is enabled as a lyrics provider

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

title: Downloading music manually using a youtubeurl and spotifyurl seems to be broken.

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### System OS

Windows

### Python Version

3.10 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

4.1.6 / commit b624e6f

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

Expected to download the desired youtube link with spotify metadata, but kicks back an error the states "Song is missing required fields: None - None "

### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links!

1. Find a youtube link you want to be the audio source
2. Find the spotify link to get metadata from

4. Error is then given

title: Playlists can contain UTF-8 and therefore should be written as .m3u8

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### System OS

Windows

### Python Version

3.7 (CPython)

### Install Source

GitHub

### Install version / commit hash

v4.1.4

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

Playlists are written with the `.m3u` extension, even when they contain UTF-8 strings like this one: `HØST`.
This can be misinterpreted by players like Foobar2000 which seem to only read the UTF-8 contents properly when the appropriate .m3u8 extension is used.

### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links!

Download a playlist with artists or titles that contain characters that require the UTF-8 encoding and attempt playing the .m3u file in Foobar2000.

### Traceback

```text
n/a
```


### Other details

_No response_

body:
### System OS

Windows

### Python Version

3.11 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

v4.1.4

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

do not download from youtube.com unless included as provider

### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links!

set
```
    "audio_providers": [
        "youtube-music"
    ],
```
in config.json

try to download https://open.spotify.com/album/22raVVPgBxkV6BtzIdjdnM?si=FE4AOvMWRgyoQuwrVuDUxg

spotdl can't find the album on youtube music and so it falls back to youtube
~~entire album~~ super long video gets downloaded for track 2 ~~maybe because it has the same name as the album title~~

~~I cancel the task because I don't want that~~

### Other details

maybe I didn't read well but I couldn't find anything about disabling fallback aside from 
```
  --audio [{youtube,youtube-music} ...]
                        The audio provider to use. You can provide more than one for fallback.
```
so I assumed that having only youtube-music there avoids downloading from youtube but no?
same thing happens with other albums

title: Downloader can not handle playlist with 230+ songs

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

labels.name: Spotify
labels.description: Issue related to spotify

body:
### System OS

Windows

### Python Version

3.8 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

v4.1.4

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

## Expected
I typed in **_"spotdl download "https://open.spotify.com/playlist/324Kb46hgU8F7KnI7EI8RF?si=bd0d012e468c4dfd&pt=3c1bd7763945b88b7b725e91c33b3009" --output D:\Medien\SpotifyDownloadsSpotdl"_** and I expected to download the playlist as it is mentioned in the help document.

## Actual Behavior
The program began to run but then it stoped with several erros mostly saying "reached maximum trys"
See Traceback for more info

## Extra
**I then splitted the playlist into smaller parts of like 50 to 70 songs and the download worked fine**

### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links!

1. Open the cmd using Win + R -> type "cmd" -> press Enter
2. Cmd opens
3. Type **_"spotdl download "https://open.spotify.com/playlist/324Kb46hgU8F7KnI7EI8RF?si=bd0d012e468c4dfd&pt=3c1bd7763945b88b7b725e91c33b3009" --output D:\Medien\SpotifyDownloadsSpotdl"_** 
(without quotation marks at the end and the beginning of course)
4. Wait for the program to try to process
5. It should stop processing now with an error
6. See Traceback 

### Traceback

title: Frozen percentage progress bar after logging back in

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### System OS

Linux (debian based distro)

### Python Version

3.10 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

v4.1.3

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

After couple of minutes of inactivity my local user is being logged out. In such case process of downloading sometimes is getting frozen and most often will never back to live. Progress bar is not updated anymore and process of downloading has to be repeated.

Expected: After being logged out and then after logging in again process should be resumed without any issues.

### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links!

1. run ```python3 -m spotdl <link>``` command preferrable passing Link to Artist
2. wait 10min for being logged out (depends on OS settings)
3. log in
4. progress cannot be properly resumed after this time of inactivity

if the process is taking longer time, the greater the probability of encountering this problem of progress freezing (therefore i mentioned about downloading all songs of given artist)
it could also make sense to check not only how re-logging affects the progress in the application, but also whether internet connection could be reestablished after being temporary unavailable

### Traceback

```text
no output. progress bar were frozen and had to be interrupted via ctrl+c command
```


### Other details

_No response_

title: All tests now redundantly require network access

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
I'm updating the Nixpkgs package. Networking is forcibly disabled in the Nix sandbox, and I don't think network should be required for `conftest`; I think this regression was introduced [here](https://github.com/spotDL/spotify-downloader/commit/88e1d944ba9d692bd30876deb6f461729f4aff85#diff-33566829172de93955cf835a5cbd7c6b96392f00b79ec4dc5fcbf40740184058R36).

### System OS

Linux

### Python Version

3.10 (CPython)

### Install version / commit hash

refs/tags/v4.1.3

### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links!

1. Disable networking
2. Run pytest
3. Observe failure

All those songs should be instrumental (without lyrics), but when I play some songs from my phone it takes noticeably a lot slower to load. body: ### System OS Windows ### Python Version 3.11 (CPython) ### Install Source pip / PyPi ### Install version / commit hash v4.1.3 ### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior I want to download this album with lyrics from Genius or Musixmatch. Expected behavior: All songs from the album are downloaded completely, and include original lyrics in English. Actual behavior: Some songs have translations from the original lyrics. For example, the song titled "Candy Necklace" is in Ukrainian, while "Paris, Texas" is in Turkish. Both are from Genius. Some songs, such as "Grandfather please..." and "Let The Light In" don't even embed lyrics from Genius at all while they're there, and unfortunately lyrics for many songs from the album are restricted in Musixmatch. I don't use AZlyrics because they're pretty strict. https://www.musixmatch.com/album/Lana-Del-Rey/Did-you-know-that-there-s-a-tunnel-under-Ocean-Blvd-1 ### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links! `cmd` `spotdl download https://open.spotify.com/album/5HOHne1wzItQlIYmLXLYfZ --lyrics genius musixmatch` ### Traceback ```text Processing query: https://open.spotify.com/album/5HOHne1wzItQlIYmLXLYfZ Found 16 songs in Did you know that there's a tunnel under Ocean Blvd (Album) Downloaded "Lana Del Rey - Sweet": https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=RNwOquJbtUw Downloaded "Lana Del Rey - Did you know that there's a tunnel under Ocean Blvd": https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=hdXDmSAWLnI Downloaded "Lana Del Rey - The Grants": https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=tEqM3-tGwyg Downloaded "Lana Del Rey - A&W": https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=z9CmgTHbDpM Downloaded "Lana Del Rey - Judah Smith Interlude": https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=gU_jcLfR0tU Downloaded "Lana Del Rey - Jon Batiste Interlude": https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=Hv9RVBW36ck Downloaded "Lana Del Rey - Candy Necklace (feat. Jon Batiste)": https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=yp093Msi4NE Downloaded "Lana Del Rey - Kintsugi": https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=CcWMVyO4_A4 Downloaded "Lana Del Rey - Paris, Texas (feat. SYML)": https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=h4VZBxBBLZE Downloaded "Lana Del Rey - Fingertips": https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=oGQ5UqObf2M Downloaded "Lana Del Rey - Grandfather please stand on the shoulders of my father while he's deep-sea fishing (feat. RIOPY)": https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=92HmXTsTRQ8 Downloaded "Lana Del Rey - Let The Light In (feat. Father John Misty)": https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=3U58T-9ocq0 Downloaded "Lana Del Rey - Fishtail": https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=CkAne7LPGn8 Downloaded "Lana Del Rey - Margaret (feat. Bleachers)": https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=ueaJj5eVUVk Downloaded "Lana Del Rey - Peppers (feat. Tommy Genesis)": https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=3CiVFAsgJXA Downloaded "Lana Del Rey - Taco Truck x VB": https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=iQ07jXaOpQ8 ``` ### Other details _No response_

https://music.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLgeWE9wvSRs7QkgMxXMEMKENilgNzQrRl

I also tried this in a new Windows VM just to be sure, & new installation of Python and SpotDL+ffmpeg.
The errors are faithfully reproduced right at the 38% mark.

The full log is attached in the following text file.
[a.error.txt](https://github.com/spotDL/spotify-downloader/files/11079509/a.error.txt)

Additionally, I also tried running the following upgrade command to check if issue has already been fixed in the dev branch.
pip install --force -U https://codeload.github.com/spotDL/spotify-downloader/zip/dev

The issue persists.

title: Error with classical music containing long file names - 'file name is too long to be shortened'

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### System OS

MacOS

### Python Version

3.9 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

v4.1.2 and also v4.1.3

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

Download stops on classical music with very long file names.
Download stops with error and traceback.
Example under 'steps to reproduce', several titles are affected in this album.

### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links!

1. spotdl 'https://open.spotify.com/track/6o0proS3JAhVIbsCZhmNAx?si=b7b01d00f176404d'

2. /Users/xxxxxxxxxxx/Library/Python/3.9/lib/python/site-packages/spotdl/utils/formatter.py:359: UserWarning: Johann Sebastian Bach - Matthäus-Passion, BWV 244, Zweiter Teil: 61a. Evangelista, Jesus "Und von der 
sechsten Stunde" - 61b. Chorus I "Der rufet dem Elias" - 61c. Evangelista "Und bald lief einer unter ihnen" - 61d. Chorus II "Halt, laß sehen" - 61e. Evangelista "Aber Jesus...: File name is too long. Using the default template. warnings.warn(

unter ihnen" - 61d. Chorus II "Halt, laß sehen" - 61e. Evangelista "Aber Jesus... is too long to be shortened. File a bug report on GitHub
```


### Other details

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred - same as above, you should be able to reproduce it with the above example.

title: Extremely large sync files

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### System OS

Linux

### Python Version

3.11 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

4.1.2

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

I expected a JSON file with the bare minimum of data needed for the sync command to function, instead I got a 150 MB file of JSON with 3285203 in it for 9 playlists containing only 554 songs. That's an average of 5930 lines per song.

### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links!

Save this script below as lists.sh and run it

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash

playlists=(
  "https://open.spotify.com/playlist/20E38Souv4jOpJdY1PXgsI?si=b4e7de3c72b24bcc"
  "https://open.spotify.com/playlist/6rAgVixolsPil4bQw5UuGw?si=e863ed31f12e45b7"
  "https://open.spotify.com/playlist/5KXC8N4oLTe8Bi8bcxrH4r?si=6514f1a96daf465e"
  "https://open.spotify.com/playlist/78H9vyT1oMj3MHukwZ98U2?si=79ca61bee95f4490"
  "https://open.spotify.com/playlist/5ZFIss65s0wWFqsrsafdNe?si=ef640fe69e6b43f3"
  "https://open.spotify.com/playlist/6T8hoV71k9gpfsMwMZb5kO?si=1c3981ffb8024b8b"
  "https://open.spotify.com/playlist/35ofgvYR46FqMcneWJBVTX?si=3d325847e9b44ef3"
  "https://open.spotify.com/playlist/2GIlqSfi3BvlSW6QN7Dlgp?si=05c77fd85e9a434d"
  "https://open.spotify.com/playlist/3w12DACpIf7CZg5C1QrzXu?si=5d25429602a34e96"
);

cd "$(dirname "$0")" || exit;

spotdl --print-errors --threads 16 --output "./lists/{list-name}/{title} - {artists}" sync "${playlists[@]}" --save-file "lists.sync.spotdl"
```

### Traceback

```text
Too long, if really needed I can upload later together with the sync file
```


### Other details

_No response_

title: Initialization of metadata variables with None + function call on those

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### System OS

Linux

### Python Version

3.7 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

4.1.3

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

Hi,
I would have fixed this myself, but I wasn't sure whether my take on this is the same as yours. I'll add a trace from a song without genres tag, but I doubt whether it's useful. 
In my opinion there are actually 2 (maybe 3?) bugs:

1. In metadata.py embed_metadata() there are multiple function calls on variables without checking whether they are None, e.g. line 132 `len(song.genres)` or line 182 `zfill()`). This can lead to errors/exceptions if they actually are `None`, for any reason.
Fix: Add `if var != None` -checks

2. For example, when using `spotdl meta` on songs not having all id3 tags values set which are used by spotdl (for me it was a song downloaded with version < 4.1.0).
Spotdl first reads existing tags from the current song file in order to carry them over into the newly created `song` object. But Spotdl tries to extracts all values found in the TAG_PRESET list (in `get_file_metadata()`), and if they don't exist they are saved into the new song object as `None`.
Summarized program flow:
`meta.py:process_file()` -> in `search.py:get_song_from_file_metadata(file)` extract old tags with `get_file_metadata()` and call `song.py:from_missing_data()` to copy them.
Fix: Check for missing tags (`==None`) and ~download the correct value from Spotify instead.


Aside from these bugs, I was wondering why `meta` operates like this. It does not just update all tags for the given song. `meta` looks whether the 5 fields artist, artists, name, lyrics, and album_art are set, and only if they aren't applies metadata. And even then, old metadata is preserved in the existing song file instead of updating it. 
The `--force-update-metadata` option skips the check for these 5 fields, but still preserves existing metadata, which is even weirder, and to me seems like a 3rd bug.


### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links!

See above

body:
### System OS

Linux

### Python Version

3.11 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

4.0.7

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

body:
### System OS

Windows

### Python Version

3.11 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

4.0.7

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

**Expected Lyrics (Song = https://open.spotify.com/track/22pjmqZq2oTZtEThEt66Zn?si=0add72687e39463e):**

Remember the feeling of my fingertips on your skin
And the way that our kisses taste sweeter after drinking

**Actuak Lyrics (Song = https://open.spotify.com/track/22pjmqZq2oTZtEThEt66Zn?si=0add72687e39463e):**

descRemember the feeling of my fingertips on your skin
And the way that our kisses taste sweeter after drinking

**Note that this happens when using genius as your lyrics provider**
**There are NO lyrics attached whatsoever when using azlyrics as your lyrics provider**


### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links!

1. Open Terminal
2. Type `spotdl download https://open.spotify.com/track/0VjIjW4GlUZAMYd2vXMi3b` OR `spotdl download https://open.spotify.com/track/0VjIjW4GlUZAMYd2vXMi3b --lyrics azlyrics`
3. Hit enter
4. Once downloaded, use a music player which also displays lyrics (for e.g. iTunes)
5. View the lyrics and see the bug
6. There is a "desc" written at the start of the lyrics when using genius
7. There are NO lyrics when using azlyrics

### Traceback

```text
Downloaded "The Weeknd - Blinding Lights": https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=J7p4bzqLvCw
```


### Other details

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/114759242/221195268-aead1b00-594a-41ac-b4d9-c18383751b03.png)

body:
### System OS

Linux

### Python Version

3.10 (CPython)

### Install Source

GitHub

### Install version / commit hash

44692213ab45b2fa80299d5c6048dabe0bfad402 (master branch) as well as ce04143c00d005c45e8bea3247125c69fac68192 (dev branch)

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

In the progress display as well as log messages, square brackets in song titles are not rendered properly, since `rich` tries to parse them as markup (like `[green]`). The saved files are – unsurprisingly – not affected.

### Other details

You seem to not understand anything about audio enconding. You should NEVER re encode audio files!

It's like I have all day to be reading others mistake, THEN why the hell select the worst encoder possible as the main source quality for your program AND WITH NO SPECIFIC FFMPEG ARGS.

title: Consider renaming the module 'types' to something else

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### System OS

Linux

### Python Version

3.10 (CPython)

### Install Source

GitHub

### Install version / commit hash

8f7cb2a7ab13f1244d1b9abc6635ccaa14b01ba7

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

# What I did

After cloning the repository I wanted to run spotify-downloader in with the PyCharm Debugger.

```
/home/xxxx/.cache/pypoetry/virtualenvs/spotdl-ruo9Hk-Z-py3.10/bin/python /home/xxxx/.local/share/JetBrains/Toolbox/apps/PyCharm-P/ch-0/223.7571.203/plugins/python/helpers/pydev/pydevd.py --multiprocess --qt-support=auto --client 127.0.0.1 --port 40149 --file /home/xxxx/workspace/spotify-downloader/spotdl/__main__.py download https://open.spotify.com/playlist/xxxxxxxxxxxxx
```

# What happened?

It crashed with the following output:

```
ImportError: cannot import name 'MappingProxyType' from partially initialized module 'types' (most likely due to a circular import) (/home/xxxx/workspace/spotify-downloader/spotdl/types/__init__.py)
```
# What I expected to happen

The debugger should run without any extra steps to perform.

### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links!

1. Open `spotify-downloader` with PyCharm
2. Run `spotdl/main.py` with the debugger

### Traceback

```text
Error in sitecustomize; set PYTHONVERBOSE for traceback:
ImportError: cannot import name 'MappingProxyType' from partially initialized module 'types' (most likely due to a circular import) (/home/xxxx/workspace/spotify-downloader/spotdl/types/__init__.py)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/xxxx/.local/share/JetBrains/Toolbox/apps/PyCharm-P/ch-0/223.7571.203/plugins/python/helpers/pydev/pydevd.py", line 8, in <module>
    from contextlib import contextmanager
  File "/usr/lib/python3.10/contextlib.py", line 6, in <module>
    from functools import wraps
  File "/usr/lib/python3.10/functools.py", line 22, in <module>
    from types import GenericAlias
  File "/home/xxxx/workspace/spotify-downloader/spotdl/types/__init__.py", line 5, in <module>
    from spotdl.types.song import Song, SongList
  File "/home/xxxx/workspace/spotify-downloader/spotdl/__init__.py", line 6, in <module>
    import asyncio
  File "/usr/lib/python3.10/asyncio/__init__.py", line 8, in <module>
    from .base_events import *
  File "/usr/lib/python3.10/asyncio/base_events.py", line 18, in <module>
    import concurrent.futures
  File "/usr/lib/python3.10/concurrent/futures/__init__.py", line 8, in <module>
    from concurrent.futures._base import (FIRST_COMPLETED,
  File "/usr/lib/python3.10/concurrent/futures/_base.py", line 7, in <module>
    import logging
  File "/usr/lib/python3.10/logging/__init__.py", line 26, in <module>
    import sys, os, time, io, re, traceback, warnings, weakref, collections.abc
  File "/usr/lib/python3.10/re.py", line 124, in <module>
    import enum
  File "/usr/lib/python3.10/enum.py", line 2, in <module>
    from types import MappingProxyType, DynamicClassAttribute
ImportError: cannot import name 'MappingProxyType' from partially initialized module 'types' (most likely due to a circular import) (/home/xxxx/workspace/spotify-downloader/spotdl/types/__init__.py)
```


### Other details

This is a known issue with python: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/43453414/cannot-import-name-mappingproxytype-error-after-importing-functools

I know that this is not a _real_ bug and could be prevented by configuring the Debug Configuration correctly, but it would have been nice to just start the debugger without any manual extra steps.

## Possible solution

The module `types` could be renamed to something with a similar meaning to prevent the name clash.

Some ideas:

* `objects`
* `datatypes`
* `dataclasses`
* `api` (since it seems like most of the spotify api endpoints are defined in there)

body:
### System OS

MacOS

### Python Version

3.9 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

v4.0.5

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

Actual: 
```bash
export my_url=https://open.spotify.com/playlist/37i9dQZF1EIghF4pN4a5k2
spotdl $my_url --output "./playlist {list-name} ({list-length} tracks)/{title}"
ls # shows "playlist Polish Techno Mix (0 tracks)
```
Expected:
```bash
ls # shows "playlist Polish Techno Mix (50 tracks)
```

When I run `spotdl $my_url --output "./playlist {list-name} ({list-length} tracks)/{title}"` or similar, it always prints `(0 tracks)` despite the playlists having multiple tracks. 

This happened with several playlists, including https://open.spotify.com/playlist/37i9dQZF1EIghF4pN4a5k2 though it's possible that the problem is that all of them were "magic" in some way ("Your top songs 2019", "Lufa song radio", or in this case a "Mix" "picked just for you"). 

### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links!

1. run script above, for convenience: 
```bash
export my_url=https://open.spotify.com/playlist/37i9dQZF1EIghF4pN4a5k2
spotdl $my_url --output "./playlist {list-name} ({list-length} tracks)/{title}"
ls 
```
2. Observe "(0 tracks)" in title, where it should have "(50 tracks")

n/a

### Python Version

### Install Source

### Install version / commit hash

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

docker container remains running, allowing me to open the docker container's console and run spotdl commands

### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links!

1. docker-compose or docker build spotdl from the docker-compose.yml and Dockerfile files in the github
2. run the docker container
3. docker container immediately exits itself, saying "spotdl: error: the following arguments are required: query"

on checking the docker container's settings i see that it's execution command is "poetry run spotdl" however i have no way to edit this

### Traceback

```text

title: Web mode download location is wrong

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

labels.name: Web UI
labels.description: Issues or PRs relating to the Web UI

body:
### System OS

Linux

### Python Version

3.10 (CPython)

### Install Source

Termux Installation Script (spotDL provided)

### Install version / commit hash

4.0.5

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

I ran web, and expected it to download the songs into the folder I ran the command from, as it says in the docs https://spotdl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/installation/#where-does-spotdl-download-songs

What it did instead was download the songs to `~/.spotdl/web/sessions/{random gui}/`. There is no notice about this, and seemingly no documentation that I could find about it. I only found the files by searching my computer for them.

The same happens in the docker version, except it downloads to `/root/.spotdl/web/sessions/{random gui}` inside the docker container.

    container_name: spot-dl
    command: web --host 0.0.0.0 --audio youtube --dont-filter-results

      - 8008:8800

title: Wrong song being found

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body: ## System OS Windows ## Python Version 3.9 (CPython) ## Install Source pip / PyPi ## Install version / commit hash 4.0.5 ## Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior Downloading **Matt Watson - No Nut November** outputs a bass guitar cover of the song instead of the actual song ### Expected ``` spotdl download https://open.spotify.com/track/1ddxqZGFM00vtzhAflKkTW Downloaded "Matt Watson - No Nut November": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kVr31ryrXQM ``` | **Info** | **Results** | |---|---| | **Video Title** | No Nut November (feat. Freddie Dredd, Kill Bill: The Rapper & Carson Tucker) | | **Channel Name** | Matt Watson - Topic| | **YT Link** | `https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kVr31ryrXQM` | ## Actual ``` spotdl download https://open.spotify.com/track/1ddxqZGFM00vtzhAflKkTW Downloaded "Matt Watson - No Nut November": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LGaKOIpYU40 ``` | **Info** | **Results** | |---|---| | **Video Title** | Matt Watson, Freddie Dredd, Kill Bill: The Rapper, Carson Tucker - NO NUT NOVEMBER [Bass Cover] | | **Channel Name** | Nick Maxwell | | **YT Link** | `https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LGaKOIpYU40` | ###### I'm purely assuming this, but is because the title matches closer to the search? It would be weird considering that the "correct result" is the first search result on yt-music... idk **Temp fix** `spotdl download "https://youtu.be/kVr31ryrXQM|https://open.spotify.com/track/1ddxqZGFM00vtzhAflKkTW"` ## Steps to reproduce `spotdl download https://open.spotify.com/track/1ddxqZGFM00vtzhAflKkTW` ## Traceback ``` FOLDER_PATH>spotdl download https://open.spotify.com/track/1ddxqZGFM00vtzhAflKkTW Downloaded "Matt Watson - No Nut November": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LGaKOIpYU40 ``` #### Other details I was considering posting this in the discord but decided against it cause there is no real place to post this other than `help`. Is it cool if I keep adding problematic songs to this git issue, or would it be easier/better for a issue per song???

title: Error on sync when using custom output and saving m3u file

body:
### System OS

Linux

### Python Version

3.10 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

4.0.4

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

I want to synchronize my songs using the sync option, while updating the m3u file using `--m3u FILE`.

My songs are playlist-based, so i use `--output "{list-name}/{title} - {artists}.{output-ext}"` to classify them

I can create the initial synchronization and generate the m3u, but cant resume the sync while using the `--m3u FILE.m3u` option

`spotdl --m3u FILE.m3u sync FILE.spotdl` works
`spotdl --output "{list-name}/{title} - {artists}.{output-ext}" sync FILE.spotdl` works
`spotdl --m3u FILE.m3u --output "{title} - {artists}.{output-ext}" sync FILE.spotdl` works

But when using m3u option alongside custom output with `{list-name}`, it doesn't
`spotdl --m3u FILE.m3u --output "{list-name}/{title} - {artists}.{output-ext}" sync FILE.spotdl` gives the error on traceback

### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links!

body:
### System OS

Linux

### Python Version

3.7 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

4.0.1

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

respect the XDG base directory spec. meaning the `.spotdl` folder created at the `~` directory should actually be created at  `~/.local/share` or in terms of the XDG spec, it should be under `XDG_DATA_HOME` as far as i know.

title: Progress percentage not accurate

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### System OS

Windows

### Python Version

3.9 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

v4.0.1

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

**Expected** 
Progress percentage and eta to be accurate.
**Actual**
If songs are skipped they don't seem to be added to the progress percentage. It just starts from 0 then counts up from there.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47313866/198004370-93cb7715-e9e7-45a5-92f1-2c14f32b4b03.png)
###### Also what is up with the search results for songs? On a new phone on a new sim I get the actual music I expect from the artists channels but all the links from spotdl seem to be from random 20-500 view videos with modified audio. I'm not complaining, this is truly great software, out of the couple thousand i have downloaded I would say every 1000 it misses around 40 and gets the wrong link (audio is different to original) wrong on around 10 of them. Would it help if it prioritized channels with "- Topic" in the name or that have the tag "Official Artist Channel", tho I don't think yt_dlp supports that. Anyway, love you guys and the work you do, btw that web UI is looking nice 👌

### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links!

**I waited until 1.5k ish originally but I'm sure any number works, just the more, the more obvious.** 
`spotdl download https://open.spotify.com/playlist/7amAY9qfwE7Lp7nMoQ5U0j`
###### Also got rate limited at 1.4k, waiting 10 mins allowed another 300 before I got limited again. Nothing on you guys, its just spotify, but is there any cooldown function that can be set?

**Running the program after getting rate limited or getting a decent chuck will now start the percentage back at 0%**
`spotdl download https://open.spotify.com/playlist/7amAY9qfwE7Lp7nMoQ5U0j`


### Traceback

```text
Comment is too long (maximum is 65536 characters)
https://pastebin.com/raw/X4jV8UkZ
```


### Other details

Got rate limited at the end, hence the invalid client and 404. If I try again after a crash I get the old 429 error 😂

title: Error when synchronizing songs with playlist-based folders

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### System OS

Linux

### Python Version

3.10 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

4.0.0-rc.5

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

I want to synchronize multiple spotify playlists at once and i want these playlists to be separated by folders
The initial `python3 -m spotdl --output "{list-name}/{title} - {artists}.{output-ext}" --save-file .sync.spotdl sync PLAYLIST1 PLAYLIST2 ...` goes ok
But when i want to continue the synchronization using `python3 -m spotdl --output "{list-name}/{title} - {artists}.{output-ext}" sync .sync.spotdl`, it directly gives an error
I noticed that the problem appears only when i want to use the "{list-name}" on the output path, otherwise seems to be ok
It happens whether the output with "{list-name}" its defined on the user config or on the cli

title: SpotifyClient wrong cache hits

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### System OS

Linux

### Python Version

3.9 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

4.0.0-rc.3

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

The cache in spotdl.utils.spotify does not work as intented. Currently the responses of the Spotify API are saved into the cache by their url. This works fine for search terms including a track-id. But if you search a song by name the url will always just be "search" and the actual search term is not part of it. Therefore if you search 2 songs by name the first response will get cached and the second has the same url "search", which causes a false cache hit. Therefore the key for the cache has to incorporate not only the url, but all other parameters of the request as well.

### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links!

1. python -m spotdl download "MYTH & ROID - shadowgraph" "MYTH & ROID - Remembrance"
2. Script downloads "MYTH & ROID - shadowgraph" 2x

### Traceback

```text
Downloaded "MYTH & ROID - shadowgraph": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FAQPxKKfjzQ
Downloaded "MYTH & ROID - shadowgraph": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FAQPxKKfjzQ
```


### Other details

_No response_

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

title: sync option: Existing song downloaded again if its name changed

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

labels.name: Stale
labels.description: Issue with no activity for the last 30 days

body:
### System OS

Linux

### Python Version

3.10 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

4.0.0-rc.2

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

Over time, the exact name of a song can change, even if the url does not, e.g.
_Vanessa Forero, Traumton - Heaven Knows - Traumton Remix.mp3
Vanessa Forero - Heaven Knows - Traumton Remix.mp3_
I think Spotify changes song names and metadata from time to time, that might be a reason.


Expected Behavior:
Songs already present should not be downloaded again. 
I personally like to download songs that were wrongfully matched manually via 
```spotdl download "YouTubeURL|SpotifyURL"```, so it would be nice if those songs won't be just overwritten. 

Actual behavior:
A song which is already present gets downloaded again with a slightly different names, leading to a song duplicate.


### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links!

1. A playlist gets downloaded and a sync-file is created
2. The name of a song changes
3. sync is used again

spotdl thinks the song is missing (since the url provides a new name which is not found within the directory) and downloads it again. 
This leads to having the same song downloaded twice.

This is hard to reproduce, since the name changes might occur at random. But using a large playlist helps. For reference: For a 660 song playlist I had approximately 48 such cases in a 2 month interval (from June 2nd to August 16th).

### Traceback

```text
[Lists of all downloaded songs]
```


### Suggested Fix

- The name alone can not be used for matching the existing song file to the url, because the name can change. Matching with the Spotify url would fix this. 
As of now, spotdl only saves the YouTube url within the *comment* ID3 tag. By changing the *comment* format to ```"YouTubeURL|SpotifyURL"```, therefore also saving the Sporify url, this would be possible. (Using the ID3 *URL link frames* instead of a *comment* is also an option, but that's a different topic).
- I think the metadata should be updated as well, but I'm not sure.

title: Deletion of local files does not work with the sync function for playlist

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### System OS

Windows

### Python Version

3.8 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

v4.0.0

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

I expected that when using spotdl sync, spotdl would delete my local tracks that were removed from my spotify playlist. 

What it actually does, is keeping the spotify removed tracks in my local folder. 

Good to know : the sync file (.spotdl) actually does not contain anymore the tracks removed from spotify. 

### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links!

1. sync a test playlist

`spotdl sync https://open.spotify.com/playlist/3iln8DxhryTXnFTLmWi1g0?si=400f5949ca6244f9 --save-file test_sync.spotdl --format mp3 --bitrate 320k --audio youtube-music --m3u test.m3u`

I properly got all the songs from the playlist in the local folder.

2. delete a track on spotify

3. Run the syncing process

`spotdl sync test_sync.spotdl`

spotdl returns me: 

`Nothing to do...`

And does not delete the tracks removed on spotify.
if I look at the `test_sync.spotdl` file, the tracks removed from spotify are not mentioned in the file.

```

title: Spotdl web cannot be selfhosted as localhost part is hardscripted

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

labels.name: Stale
labels.description: Issue with no activity for the last 30 days

labels.name: Web UI
labels.description: Issues or PRs relating to the Web UI

body:
### System OS

Linux

### Python Version

3.10 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

v4.0.0rc1

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

Expected Behaviour:
The command `spotdl web` should respect config values and take an endpoint that is not localhost to allow selfhosting

Actual Behaviour:
The command `spotdl web` just 'stupidly' pulls a pre-compiled js file that has BACKEND='localhost' hardscripted into it which does not allow proper selfhosting

### Steps to reproduce - Ensure to include actual links!

1. Create a Nginx reverse proxy and put spotdl behind it
2. Visit the site you created
3. Try any search query and see how in the network tab it tries to query localhost

### Traceback

```text
Cross-Origin Request Blocked: The Same Origin Policy disallows reading the remote resource at http://localhost:8800/api/songs/search?query=dwa. (Reason: CORS request did not succeed).

Firefox can’t establish a connection to the server at ws://localhost:8800/api/ws?client_id=d708ec76-6883-4fd5-8ece-d05137cf3fa1.
```


### Other details

An easy way to fix this, would be to provide a config option for setting the variables and then build the js file based on these values instead of just plainly getting the files from a dist folder inside another repo

After upgrading to v4 and attempting to use spotdl, spotdl's ffmpeg path is not set. An example command is given for updating the path, but the command does not appear to work.

### System Operating System (OS)

MacOS

### Python Version

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

I am downloading couple of playlists so I have made a script and always there is one song stuck at "Converting".
It works fine if I directly call `spotdl` in the terminal with one playlist.

The  script:

```
#!/bin/bash

while IFS=';' read -r name addr; do 
	echo $name
	mkdir $name
	cd $name
	spotdl "$addr" --dt 8 --st 8
	cd ..
done < dl

title: Exclude termux and tests folder in package

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### System Operating System (OS)

Linux

### Python Version

3.10 (CPython)

### Install Source

Arch User Repository (Unofficial)

### Install version / commit hash

v3.9.6

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

I'm one of maintainers of https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/python-spotdl package and the problem we faced was that `python-spotdl` package was installing tests folder in `/usr/lib/python3.10/site-packages/tests/__init__.py` instead of its folder (`/usr/lib/python3.10/site-packages/python-spotdl`).
```
/usr/lib/python3.10/site-packages/tests/__init__.py exists in filesystem (owned by python-spotdl)
/usr/lib/python3.10/site-packages/tests/__pycache__/__init__.cpython-310.opt-1.pyc exists in filesystem (owned by python-spotdl)
/usr/lib/python3.10/site-packages/tests/__pycache__/__init__.cpython-310.pyc exists in filesystem (owned by python-spotdl)
```
The solution Arch official guidelines suggest is to remove `tests` folder manually after packaging (https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/Python_package_guidelines#Test_directory_in_site-package)
So this was added to PKGBUILD:
```
	local site_packages=$(python -c "import site; print(site.getsitepackages()[0])")
	rm -rf "${pkgdir}${site_packages}/tests/"
```

But I guess this is something that should be fixed upstream, so I came up with this PR.

A [suggestion](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/python-spotdl#comment-865789) was to change `packages = find:` to `packages = spotdl`, but after some searching I reached [this change](https://github.com/spotDL/spotify-downloader/commit/bee7b76924c3b03ac41ec63367539e3cee675620) instead.

### Steps to reproduce

On Arch Linux
```
git clone https://aur.archlinux.org/python-spotdl.git
cd python-spotdl
makepkg -sri
```

### Traceback

```text
There isn't an error.
```


### Other details

I was opening a PR until I see there should be an issue before opening a PR, that's why I'm here.

title: SpotifyException HTTP404 Error, HTTP Error for GET - Cannot download songs

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### System Operating System (OS)

Linux

### Python Version

3.8 (CPython)

### Install Source

GitHub

### Install version / commit hash

3.9.4

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

I was trying to download a playlist containing a bigger amount of songs.
I noticed that while fetching the names and looking them up on YouTube, I got random HTTP 404 on requests going to Spotify.
With every run, it randomly appears on songs, that definitely exist (I checked the URL manually).

I'm guessing, that there is a rate limit or something similar on Spotify's end.

My suggestion - that I also already tested locally - would be to retry the failed requests instead of exiting out and to continue downloading the rest instead of just failing.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Try to download a huge playlist

### Traceback

    response.raise_for_status()

    raise HTTPError(http_error_msg, response=self)

    parse_request(

    song_list = song_gatherer.from_playlist(
  File "/**/venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/spotdl/search/song_gatherer.py", line 359, in from_playlist
    for result in results:

    result = self.fn(*self.args, **self.kwargs)
  File "/**/venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/spotdl/search/song_gatherer.py", line 320, in get_song
    song = from_spotify_url(
  File "/**/venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/spotdl/search/song_gatherer.py", line 43, in from_spotify_url

    return self._get("tracks/" + trid, market=market)
  File "/**/venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/spotipy/client.py", line 297, in _get

  File "/**/venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/spotipy/client.py", line 267, in _internal_call
    raise SpotifyException(
spotipy.exceptions.SpotifyException: http status: 404, code:-1 - https://api.spotify.com/v1/tracks/22ea9e9wspXjaR7qfqfsdS:
 None, reason: None
```


### Other details

Easy to go solution would be to wrap "from_url" with the "retry" decorator (https://pypi.org/project/retry/)

body:
### System Operating System (OS)

Linux

### Python Version

3.8 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

Version: 3.9.3

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

I expected to see the letters/words show as I typed "spotdl  [URL]" 
e.g. - `spotdl https://open.spotify.com/album/4QtoNIqTWR3e5NVb833Bj2`
 BUT
upon the 2nd time I typed "spotdl  [URL]" in the same terminal session the typed letters did not show.
I did discover that if I typed "spotdl [URL]" anyway, (even though I could not see the letters) and hit ENTER, it still worked.

### Steps to reproduce

1. open a terminal [bash Konsole]
2. type spotdl [URL] << typed letters show 1st time 
3. `la@localhost:~> spotdl https://open.spotify.com/album/4QtoNIqTWR3e5NVb833Bj2`
4. spotdl gets songs, converts them and places them in a designated folder.
5. type spotdl [URL] << typed letters do NOT show 2nd, 3rd, 4th, ad infinitum, until terminal is closed.
6. spotdl does work if I continue to type "spotdl"  and paste the [URL] in and hit ENTER. 
7. It looks like this: `la@localhost:~> `
8. The typed and pasted letters/words just don't show.
9. 
10. 

### Traceback

```text
There is no error message.
```


### Other details

openSUSE Tumbleweed. KDE Desktop. I don't know of anything else that would be pertinent, but please let me know what I can do to give more info. Thanks

title: RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### System Operating System (OS)

Linux

### Python Version

3.9 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

v3.9.2

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

Expected Behavior:

Song is download with a filename following the path-template specified.

Actual Behavior:

When downloading certain songs, spotDL errors out if a path-template is specified; stating a RecursionError. I have observed this on "Lump" by "The Presidents of the United States of America" and "Peaches" by the same band. Perhaps it it something with the long length of the artist name? The path template used is '{playlist}/{artists}/{album}/{title} - {artists} - {album}.{ext}'. 

When downloading without a path-template, those two songs downloads fine. Almost every other song that I tried downloaded fine with and without the same path-tempate.

### Steps to reproduce

`spotdl https://open.spotify.com/track/2JdzB67NvIa90K4gEZPLeX?si=bf3d9b2d177b4754 --path-template '{playlist}/{artists}/{album}/{title} - {artists} - {album}.{ext}'`

and also

`spotdl https://open.spotify.com/track/3VEFybccRTeWSZRkJxDuNR?si=db31064fe5124112 --path-template '{playlist}/{artists}/{album}/{title} - {artists} - {album}.{ext}'`

title: spotdl gives low quality ogg transcodes

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### System OS

Linux

### Python Version

3.8 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

3.9.1

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

When specifying ogg as an output format, I expect decent quality audio files (112kb/s or higher), but instead I get 64kb/s audio files.

This also occurs with m4a, where I expect 128 kb/s but get a nominal 98 kb/s.

### Steps to reproduce

1. use `spotdl --of ogg` to download a song
2. use `youtube-dl -f bestaudio -x --audio-format vorbis` to download the same audio 
3. use ffprobe to observe the bitrates of both files and see that the bitrate is lower for spotdl's file

### Traceback

```text
N/A
```


### Other details

I don't really know if this counts as a "bug", but it's definitely an undesirable functionality which is very easy to fix. I had hardcoded a fix for this into my instance of the program, but decided I might as well do it properly, and I've already prepared a patch for this which hopefully demonstrates why this is a problem. You can see the patch here: https://github.com/nejni-marji/spotify-downloader/commit/c396551c6d82c3348d587413b6c5bb35741f8aa7

title: Specifying both the ffmpeg location and output parameter attempts to find ffmpeg in output folder instead of the working directory

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### System OS

Windows

### Python Version

3.9 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

v3.9.0

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

When specifying both the -f flag and --output flags, spotdl attempts to find the ffmpeg binary in the output folder instead of the current working directory.

A simple fix is to just to use the relative path, from the output directory. But in my eyes that's not expected behaviour.

### Steps to reproduce

mkdir library
cp /ffmpeg .

spotdl -f ./ffmpeg --output library 'Adele - Rolling in the deep'



### Traceback

```text
FFmpeg was not found, spotDL cannot continue.
```


### Other details

This happens as the library is changing directory to the output folder [as seen here](https://github.com/spotDL/spotify-downloader/blob/master/spotdl/console/__init__.py#L57).

Whereas it's my belief that we should use the pathlib library to amend the filepaths of which we're searching and downloading songs to.

Thing is, all parts of the soundtrack are fully available on YouTube. Is there a fix for this bug? Is there a playlist downloader I can use until this is fixed? Thanks. 

### Steps to reproduce

Command: spotdl https://open.spotify.com/album/5oEzjkSYSfC0ITRiqK6m8l --output-format flac

### Traceback

```text
Fetching Album...
Could not match any of the results on YouTube. Skipping
```


### Other details

_No response_

### System OS

### Python Version

### Install Source

GitHub

### Install version / commit hash

v3.9.0

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

To download songs and seems to be doing so. I do not know what this error means. It asked me to report it lol.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Open Windows Powershell
2. Select where you want the songs to download to (ex: H:) (usb drive)
3. type (spotdl https://open.spotify.com/playlist/4IVC6SId5jvTLPSItS2bOM?si=391648fecc4c4452 --use-youtube)
4. Let it run

select usb drive

body:
### System OS

Windows

### Python Version

3.9 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

3.9.0

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

_No response_

### Steps to reproduce

1. Install Python 3.10
2. Add to Path Python 3.10 folder and bin folder
3. Install FFmpeg and add _bin_ folder to Path
4. Use console command: py -m spotdl *LINK*

### Traceback

```text
\Python310\lib\runpy.py:126: RuntimeWarning: 'spotdl.__main__' found in sys.modules after import of package 'spotdl', but prior to execution of 'spotdl.__main__'; this may result in unpredictable behaviour

FFmpeg was not found, spotDL cannot continue.
```


### Other details

**I HAVE PYTHON 3.10 INSTALLED**
so I have just installed python 3.10 and ffmpeg and decided to use spotdl as I did in the good old days but now it results in the runtimewarning error. I don't know if it really can't find FFmpeg but I can assure you that it is installed correctly and its location is in Path.
I also tried (just in case):
`py -m pip install ffmpeg`
but it didn't help either.
Any idea how to fix it?

title: Error with path template option when the path contain a dot at the beginning or the end of a folder

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### System OS

Windows

### Python Version

3.9 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

3.9.0

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

- When the operating system is Windows
- when the --path-template option is used
- when in the path, one of the folders starts or ends with a dot,
- then an exception of type FileNotFoundError is thrown.

Under Windows, to create a folder starting with a dot, you must add a dot at the end of the folder. The end dot is automatically deleted.
It is not recommended to create a folder ending with a dot, this causes an error in the ntfs addressing.

The simplest solution is to systematically delete the dots at the beginning and at the end of the folder.

_Exemple :_
spotdl https://open.spotify.com/track/3EGhPWuff3qSJ6E3FDQSQZ --path-template "{artist}\{album}\{artist} - {album} - {title}.{ext}"

_Output :_ 
FileNotFoundError: [WinError 3] Le chemin d’accès spécifié est introuvable: 'Sigur Rós\\Takk...\\Sigur Rós - Takk... - Með Blóðnasir.mp3'

open a windows command prompt

Spotdl successfully fetched whole album and downloaded it. But as the 'tagging' process started I saw some glitch and a message [popped up](https://imgur.com/a/r99Wy8o) on the display: python has stopped working. So I thought of raising an issue so that our lovely developers/contributors can fix the issue. Being a normie, I am not even sure if it's spotdl's issue or python's issue. The album folder kinda looks like [this ](https://imgur.com/a/Oa1EYcB)now.

Anyway, I thought I should let you know guys. Love you, bless you. Ya'll are doin' God's work. Peace.

title: .m3u generation results in broken playlist

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### System OS

Linux

### Python Version

3.9 (CPython)

### Install Source

pip / PyPi

### Install version / commit hash

v3.7.0

### Expected Behavior vs Actual Behavior

When passing the --m3u, --generate-m3u argument for a playlist download query, the resulting .m3u created is not usable on linux systems. This is due to the track file names within not matching the case of the file name. The file names have capitalized letters and the filenames contained within the m3u data appear to all be lowercase. Spaces and symbols are all in place and file extension is correct.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Download playlist with --m3u or --generate-m3u argument.
2. Attempt to play m3u with audio player. (I have used VLC and QMMP)

### Traceback

```text
No error is generated.
```


### Other details

Since there are no options to configure the output filename with track-number, artist, etc. this m3u is the only way to preserve the order of the playlist. Manually correcting the m3u file is quite tedious. I would like the ability to generate m3u for album downloads also for this same reason. But I think that is a feature request so ill bite my tongue. :P

title: Bug: Downloading doesnt work in MENAP countries.

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
Youtube Music is not available in many countries, especially MENAP ones,  hence it just skips each song I put in the playlist

### Environment

- **System OS:**  Windows

- **Python Version:** 3.9.4 

- **Install Source:** `pip install spotDL
`

### Expected Behaviour

Downloads should work normally.

### Actual Behaviour

Skips the song as if it couldn't find it.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Change VPN to a country where Youtube Music is not available
2. Try downloading a song.

title: Document improvement suggestion: Installing, updating spotdl under Cygwin; "Failed to build rapidfuzz"

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### Environment

- **System OS:** Windows 10

- **Python Version:** Python 3.9.5

- **Install/Update Source:** `pip install spotdl`


- **Version OR Commit hash:**

```
$ pip show spotdl
Name: spotdl
Version: 3.6.1
```
The [spotDL installation guide](https://github.com/spotDL/spotify-downloader/blob/master/docs/INSTALLATION.md) currently explains how to install spotDL within a "Windows Command Prompt / Powershell environment" in which Python is set up via the python Windows installer and setting up `PATH`.

I in turn am a Cygwin user, where Python and other tools can be installed with the Cygwin package manager, e.g. by installing the packages 

```
python3
python-pip-wheel
gcc-core
gcc-g++
```

I ran into some problems while trying to install / update spotDL under Cygwin, in particular with the `rapidfuzz` wheel
* `Failed to build rapidfuzz`
  * `'cc1plus' not found`
  * `Python.h: No such file or directory`

I was able to resolve these issues by installing the following Cygwin packages:

```
libisl-devel
libisl13
libisl15
libisl22
libisl23
python3-devel
python38-devel
```

Having not much knowledge of Python, it took me some time to find out which Cygwin packages are required to install and update spotDL for my environment (there could be even more Cygwin packages required than those listed above, especially some gcc stuff, of which I already had installed a bunch in my environment before installing spotDL).

Maybe it is helpful for other users as well to expand the [spotDL Windows installation guide](https://github.com/spotDL/spotify-downloader/blob/master/docs/INSTALLATION.md) with a small section about Cygwin, listing above packages.

title: Song Download Mismatch (Wrong Download/No Downloaded)

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
<!--- Please search existing bugs before creating a new one -->

<!--- Format your issue titles as 'Error: Description' -->

<!--- example title: "FileNotFoundError: error while downloading individual songs." -->

<!--- You can also talk to us on our Discord https://discord.gg/xCa23pwJWY -->

### Environment

- **System OS:** <!--- Windows/OSX/Linux/Heroku/Docker --> Windows 10

- **Python Version:** <!--- Python Version can be found by running "py -V" --> Python 3.9.4

- **Install Source:** CMD, pip

<!--- Did you download from pip, or from GitHub? -->

<!--- Provide the command you used to install spotDL -->

- **Version OR Commit hash:**

```Name: spotdl
Version: 3.5.2
Summary: Download your Spotify playlists and songs along with album art and metadata
Home-page: https://github.com/spotDL/spotify-downloader
Author: spotDL Team
Author-email: spotdladmins@googlegroups.com
License: MIT
Location: c:\pl\python39\lib\site-packages
Requires: pytube, beautifulsoup4, mutagen, tqdm, spotipy, ytmusicapi, rapidfuzz, requests, rich
Required-by:
```

<!--- If from pip, what is the version? Run "pip show spotdl" --> 

<!--- If not from pip, what is the commit hash? -->

______________________________________________________________________

### Expected Behaviour

<!--- What did you expect to happen? -->

1. I'm trying to download The Longest Johns' Oak & Ash & Thorn, and expect that it downloads this video: https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=4GT59EqPlUQ&list=RDAMVM4GT59EqPlUQ. 
* The program will convert the whole hour, which isn't really a good thing to see since it's really just a small song, therefore the system to search the song has a wrong download
2. I'm trying to download chumachechaya vesna/Чумачечая Весна and it doesn't detect the Youtube Music link: https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=A-PjXUzhFDk&list=RDAMVMA-PjXUzhFDk 
* The program will instead error out, and this is possibly actually due to its foreign characters being recognized. Translating it to English creates a "song not found" error on Spotify, and manually typing it creates a "song not found" on Youtube instead.

### Actual Behaviour

<!--- What actually happened? -->

For Oak & Ash & Thorn, it downloads this 1 hour video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zIHmPlI4JEs
For Chumachechaya Vesna, the song can't be found.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Run "spotdl https://open.spotify.com/track/38FCXf9CTcH9MJKn3WsJ7x"
2. Run "spotdl https://open.spotify.com/track/2eaSMmKfigsm96aTUJMoIk"

Skipping Чумачечая весна (https://open.spotify.com/track/2eaSMmKfigsm96aTUJMoIk) as no match could be found on youtube
```

title: Second pull of a spotfiy playlist returns undefined/ error code

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### Environment
- docker (debian)

- master up-to-date

- **Install Source:** 
npm/ dockerfile in source

- **Version OR Commit hash:**
https://github.com/spotDL/spotify-downloader/commit/3c66180e73461083e4d9d3bb0b938038e081594e

---------

### Expected Behaviour
i can re run spotifiy downloader for the same url over and over and get a success exit code in commandline

### Actual Behaviour
it returns "undefined" and throws a SIGTERM or ERR

### Steps to Reproduce
```
#!/bin/bash
trap 'echo "oh no!"' ERR SIGTERM

declare -A sources=(
        ["Command & Conquer: Red Alert 2 (Original Soundtrack)"]="https://open.spotify.com/album/0mL0e9FMnDXyZieyyrpH1q?si=gvJ8jKWWRSSrF3cRDbXVRw"
)
    spotifyPath="/tmp"
    for sourceKey in "${!sources[@]}";
    do
        source=${sources[$sourceKey]}
        
        echo "Downloading ${sourceKey}"
        docker run -u $(id -u):$(id -g) -v ${spotifyPath}:/download:rw --rm phyzical/spotify-dl "$source"
    done
    
    echo "Finished Spotify Download!!"
```
1. above is the bash script, first run will download and return a valid exit code
2. if you re run for the same playlist url i get the following 
```
Downloading Command & Conquer: Red Alert 2 (Original Soundtrack)
- Searching…
ℹ Total Songs: 16
ℹ Saving Album: /download/Command & Conquer: Red Alert 2 (Original Soundtrack) - EA Music
ℹ Fetching cache to resume Download

undefined
oh no!
Finished Spotify Download!!
```
the reason i hoped it would return a similar exit code is i trap on SIGTERM or ERR to send notifications of an issue when running these

also note the trap isnt hit the first time only on subsequent attempts of the playlist

thanks in advance!

title: Doesnt download podcast episodes, tries to search based on song name instead

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### Environment
- **OS**: Windows

- **Python Version:** 3.9.2

- **Install Source:** 
`pip install spotdl`

- **Version OR Commit hash:**
Version: 3.4.0

---------

### Expected Behavior
Download podcast episode from spotify 

### Actual Behavior
Tries to search based on song name instead

### Steps to Reproduce
run: 
`spotdl https://open.spotify.com/episode/1xEADlBcc5mZTJL2ZelP7S`

---------

### Traceback

```
No song named "https://open.spotify.com/episode/1xEADlBcc5mZTJL2ZelP7S" could be found on spotify
  0%|                                                                         |ETA: ?, ~min/song
```

title: setup: Use the proper name for beautifulsoup4

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
`bs4` is just a metapackage to pull in `beautifulsoup4`, so not all distributions have it in their repositories.

Fixes: #1209

title: DistributionNotFound: setup.cfg uses "wrong" beautifulsoup4

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
### Environment
- **System OS:** Arch Linux

- **Python Version:** 3.9.2

- **Install Source:** 
Manual `setup.py build` and `setup.py install` from the latest tagged release.

- **Version OR Commit hash:**
Tag v3.4.0

### Expected Behaviour
spotdl should not throw an Exception.

### Actual Behaviour
spotdl threw an Exception.

### Steps to Reproduce
Install spotdl on a system that only has the `beautifulsoup4` package, not the `bs4` package (because `bs4` is just a metapackage to pull in `beautifulsoup4`, so not all distributions have it in their repository).

---------

### Traceback

<!--- Place traceback here, between the  ```  symbols -->
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/spotdl", line 33, in <module>
    sys.exit(load_entry_point('spotdl==3.4.0', 'console_scripts', 'spotdl')())
  File "/usr/bin/spotdl", line 25, in importlib_load_entry_point
    return next(matches).load()

<!--- Please search existing bugs before creating a new one -->

<!--- You can also talk to us on our Discord https://discord.gg/xCa23pwJWY -->

### Environment
- **System OS:** Ubuntu Server (uname -a: `Linux example.com 5.4.0-58-generic #64-Ubuntu SMP Wed Dec 9 08:16:25 UTC 2020 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux`)<!--- Windows/OSX/Linux/Heroku/Docker -->

- **Install Source:** I used this method form [#1135](https://github.com/spotDL/spotify-downloader/issues/1135#issuecomment-763157858):
```
# reinstall.sh
sudo pip install pip-autoremove
sudo pip-autoremove spotdl
sudo pip cache purge
sudo pip install https://codeload.github.com/spotDL/spotify-downloader/zip/master
sudo pip-autoremove pytube
sudo pip install --no-cache-dir git+https://github.com/pytube/pytube

pip

Script should actually be finding the song that exists on Youtube Music

I was expecting when SpotDL sees a private video after scraping the data, that it would skip it

### Actual Behaviour

SpotDL crashed to the commandline and stopped downloading the Spotify playlist.

title: ValueError: time data 'x views' does not match format '%H:%M:%S'

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Unexpected problem or unintended behavior that needs to be fixed

body:
<!--- Please search existing bugs before creating a new one -->
<!--- Format your issue titles as 'Error: Description' -->
<!--- example title: "FileNotFoundError: error while downloading individual songs." -->
<!--- You can also talk to us on our Discord https://discord.gg/xCa23pwJWY -->

### Environment
- **System OS:** <!--- Windows/OSX/Linux/Heroku/Docker --> Windows 10

- **Python Version:** <!--- Python Version can be found by running "py -V" --> Python 3.8.2

- **Install Source:** pip install https://codeload.github.com/spotDL/spotify-downloader/zip/dev
<!--- Did you download from pip, or from GitHub? --> 
<!--- Provide the command you used to install spotDL --> 

- **Version OR Commit hash:** 3.3.0
<!--- If from pip, what is the version? Run "pip show spotdl" --> 
<!--- If not from pip, what is the commit hash? -->

---------

### Expected Behaviour
<!--- What did you expect to happen? -->
spotDL downloads a song as normal. In this case Tina Turner - The Best / Adele - Someone Like You or Adele / Send My Love (To Your New Lover) are all not downloading.

### Actual Behaviour
<!--- What actually happened? -->
It throws an error (ValueError: time data 'x views' does not match format '%H:%M:%S') and does not download the song.

### Steps to Reproduce
1. run either of these commands:
 - spotdl https://open.spotify.com/track/6pPWRBubXOBAHnjl5ZIujB?si=6vqfB4XGT-Kii994R2xMDg
 - spotdl https://open.spotify.com/track/6QPKYGnAW9QozVz2dSWqRg?si=mjKUTaagTFGDRFPzIfEA5g
 - spotdl https://open.spotify.com/track/3KZcrZ36LW9RnChK1iIkth?si=Usp0yewrRq2ShmonF-1qyQ
2. Get the error
 

---------

### Traceback

<!--- Place traceback here, between the  ```  symbols -->
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "g:\python\lib\runpy.py", line 193, in _run_module_as_main
    return _run_code(code, main_globals, None,

    exec(code, run_globals)

    song = SongObj.from_url(request)
  File "g:\python\lib\site-packages\spotdl\search\songObj.py", line 63, in from_url
    youtubeLink = SongObj.searchProvider(
  File "g:\python\lib\site-packages\spotdl\search\provider.py", line 253, in search_and_get_best_match
    results = search_and_order_ytm_results(
  File "g:\python\lib\site-packages\spotdl\search\provider.py", line 147, in search_and_order_ytm_results
    results = __query_and_simplify(get_ytm_search_query(songName, songArtists))
  File "g:\python\lib\site-packages\spotdl\search\provider.py", line 122, in __query_and_simplify
    return list(map(__map_result_to_song_data, searchResult))
  File "g:\python\lib\site-packages\spotdl\search\provider.py", line 95, in __map_result_to_song_data
    'length': __parse_duration(result['duration']),
  File "g:\python\lib\site-packages\spotdl\search\provider.py", line 78, in __parse_duration
    x = strptime(padded, '%H:%M:%S')
  File "g:\python\lib\_strptime.py", line 562, in _strptime_time
    tt = _strptime(data_string, format)[0]
  File "g:\python\lib\_strptime.py", line 349, in _strptime
    raise ValueError("time data %r does not match format %r" %
ValueError: time data '4.7K views' does not match format '%H:%M:%S'

---------

### Any other information:

From my limited understanding of things, it looks like spotDL somehow gets the views of the video instead of the time.

Possibly related to #1119 and #1110

body:
### Environment
- **System OS:** Windows 10 Pro

- **Python Version:** 3.9.0

- **Install Source:** 
spotDL from pip,

- **Version OR Commit hash:**
v3.2.1

------------------------------------------------------------

### Expected Behaviour
File to download.

### Actual Behaviour
Files with commas will cause spotDL to hang. There will be no final `.mp3` file.

### Steps to Reproduce
`spotdl https://open.spotify.com/track/4dASQiO1Eoo3RJvt74FtXB?si=chrT9CZPT9m5_Nkz89acaw`
OR 
`https://open.spotify.com/track/1bG6qffAzpyiqwZz4zytTt`

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### Traceback

Since spotDl hangs, there is no Traceback usually. You can get the traceback by Interrupting the process, (`Control+C`) on Win.

```

FileNotFoundError: [WinError 2] The system cannot find the file specified: '.\\Lil Wayne - Sucker for Pain (with Wiz Khalifa, Imagine Dragons, Logic & Ty Dolla $ign feat. X Ambassadors).mp3'

**Song Names with dollar signs ($) in them will cause spotDL to hang.**

body:
<!--- Please search existing bugs before creating a new one -->
<!--- Format your issue titles as 'Error: Description' -->
<!--- example title: "FileNotFoundError: error while downloading individual songs." -->

### Environment
- **System OS:** Windows

- **Python Version:** Python 3.9.1

- **Install Source:** 
Download from pip with command ```pip install spotdl -U -I```

- **Version OR Commit hash:**
Name: spotdl
Version: 3.2.1
Summary: Downloads Spotify music from Youtube with metadata and album art
Home-page: https://github.com/spotDL/spotify-downloader
Author: spotDL Team
Author-email: unrealengin71+PyPi@gmail.com
License: MIT
Location: c:\pl\python39\lib\site-packages
Requires: rapidfuzz, spotipy, ytmusicapi, pytube, mutagen, tqdm, requests
Required-by:

------------------------------------------------------------

### Expected Behaviour
After Spotdl version 3 released, the application now uses Youtube Music. Now, I am downloading Chumachechaya Vesna, and the music should match both Spotify, Youtube Music and the offline one. (extra seconds notwithstanding).

Spotify link:
https://open.spotify.com/track/2eaSMmKfigsm96aTUJMoIk?si=Vj7CmhXxTzyYb5KexG-5Dg
Youtube Music match:
https://music.youtube.com/watch?v=A-PjXUzhFDk&feature=share

### Actual Behaviour
Spotdl downloads this weird rock version of the song. Retrying can make Spotdl not spot the song at all.

### Steps to Reproduce
1. ```spotdl https://open.spotify.com/track/2eaSMmKfigsm96aTUJMoIk?si=Vj7CmhXxTzyYb5KexG-5Dg```

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### Traceback

<!--- Place traceback here, between the  ```  symbols -->
```

Searching for: Potap & Nastya - Чумачечая весна
Skipping Чумачечая весна (https://open.spotify.com/track/2eaSMmKfigsm96aTUJMoIk?si=Vj7CmhXxTzyYb5KexG-5Dg) as no match could be found on youtube
  0%|                                                                                                |ETA: ?, ~min/song

D:\Downloads\Music\Spotdl>spotdl https://open.spotify.com/track/2eaSMmKfigsm96aTUJMoIk?si=Vj7CmhXxTzyYb5KexG-5Dg
Fetching Song...
Searching for: Potap & Nastya - Чумачечая весна
Skipping Чумачечая весна (https://open.spotify.com/track/2eaSMmKfigsm96aTUJMoIk?si=Vj7CmhXxTzyYb5KexG-5Dg) as no match could be found on youtube
  0%|                                                                                                |ETA: ?, ~min/song

D:\Downloads\Music\Spotdl>spotdl https://open.spotify.com/track/2eaSMmKfigsm96aTUJMoIk?si=Vj7CmhXxTzyYb5KexG-5Dg
Fetching Song...
Searching for: Potap & Nastya - Чумачечая весна
 95%|████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████▌    |ETA: 00:04, 1.65min/songc:\pl\python39\lib\site-packages\tqdm\std.py:531: TqdmWarning: clamping frac to range [0, 1]
  full_bar = Bar(frac,
100%|████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████|ETA: 00:00, ~min/song

D:\Downloads\Music\Spotdl>

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### Any other information:
At least spotdl works now! And if only I wasn't that picky, and there's this alternative called [ytmdl](https://ytmdl.deepjyoti30.dev/) that didn't have to add extra seconds but can use other metadata locations, if it didn't decide to be OS-picky, I'd not report this.
